sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine — For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Let’s kick off June with some fresh inspiration! Artists and designers from across the globe once again tickled their creativity to celebrate the beginning of the new month with a collection of beautiful and unique wallpaper calendars.
articles.title: Ice Cream Ahead (June 2024 Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Geoff Graham)
articles.description: What does it mean to learn the “basics”, or fundamentals, of front-end web development? Is starting with HTML and CSS still the best entry point to learn how to make websites and apps when we have a seemingly endless supply of frameworks? Geoff Graham thinks so and discusses why you might consider going “back to basics” to start or move forward in your career.
articles.title: In Praise Of The Basics

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: Imagine finally resolving never-ending discussions about UI decisions for good. Here are some practical examples of decision trees for UI components and how to use them effectively. An upcoming part of [Smart Interface Design Patterns](https://smart-interface-design-patterns.com).
articles.title: Decision Trees For UI Components

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Atila Fassina)
articles.description: Application frameworks have built whole ecosystems on top of them. Let’s take a closer look at serverless platforms such as Netlify’s [Platform Primitives](https://www.netlify.com/platform/primitives) and explore how they can increase our productivity with a serverless fullstack experience.
articles.title: The Era Of Platform Primitives Is Finally Here

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Daniel Yuschick)
articles.description: After years of relying on checkbox hacks to create a “switch” control for forms that toggle between two states, HTML may be gaining a native way to go about it by adding a `switch` attribute to checkbox inputs. Daniel Yuschick walks us through a first impression of switch controls and discusses current and ongoing considerations that need to be explored further before it is ready for prime time.
articles.title: Switching It Up With HTML’s Latest Control

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: How can we get better at naming? This post is dedicated to naming conventions, tips, and real-world examples that help you name things in a robust and flexible way.
articles.title: Best Practices For Naming Design Tokens, Components And Variables

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Brecht De Ruyte)
articles.description: It’s easy to get lost in a sea of CSS frameworks and libraries, each promising easier styling and smoother layouts. Brecht De Ruyte demonstrates four CSS utility classes (plus a bonus) using techniques that allow them to be used practically anywhere you need a particular layout — be it Grid or Flexbox — with configurable options.
articles.title: Modern CSS Layouts: You Might Not Need A Framework For That

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: Should you hide or disable a feature? You’ve probably been there before. Here are some considerations for hiding versus disabling, along with possible alternatives to improve UX. An upcoming part of [Smart Interface Design Patterns](https://smart-interface-design-patterns.com).
articles.title: Hidden vs. Disabled In UX

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Talke Hoppmann-Walton)
articles.description: Many organizations prioritize internal structures and services over customer-centricity, hindering effective decision-making. Through a case study, Talke Hoppmann-Walton advocates for a shift towards an outside-in perspective and proposes the use of a user segmentation matrix to foster alignment across departments and prioritize customer needs.
articles.title: Building A User Segmentation Matrix To Foster Cross-Org Alignment

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Juan Diego Rodríguez)
articles.description: Juan Diego Rodriguez explains why media queries still occupy a vital role in responsive layouts; only they are now one tool in a larger toolbox with modern techniques that are best when used together.
articles.title: Beyond CSS Media Queries

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Chris Day)
articles.description: Is there such a thing as harmony between designers and developers in the workplace, and if so, how can it be achieved? In this article, Chris Day explores the challenges of effective collaboration, outlines the key factors at play, and (hopefully!) empowers you to find the right solutions to help you and your team deliver to their full potential.
articles.title: Transforming The Relationship Between Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: How do we conduct UX research when there is no or only limited access to users? Here are some workarounds to run UX research or make a strong case for it. An upcoming part of [Smart Interface Design Patterns](https://smart-interface-design-patterns.com).
articles.title: Why Designers Aren’t Understood

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Preethi Sam)
articles.description: Preethi Sam walks through an example that demonstrates where custom properties are more suitable than variables while showcasing the greater freedom and flexibility that custom properties provide for designing complex, refined animations.
articles.title: The Times You Need A Custom @property Instead Of A CSS Variable

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Temani Afif)
articles.description: In this comprehensive guide, Temani Afif explores different techniques for creating common shapes with the smallest and most flexible code possible.
articles.title: The Modern Guide For Making CSS Shapes

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Lazar Nikolov)
articles.description: React Server Components (RSCs) combine the best of client-side rendering, and author Lazar Nikolov thoroughly examines how we got here with a deep look at the impact that RSCs have on the page load timeline.
articles.title: The Forensics Of React Server Components (RSCs)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: How do we conduct UX research when there is no or only limited access to users? Here are some workarounds to run UX research or make a strong case for it. An upcoming part of Smart Interface Design Patterns.
articles.title: How To Run UX Research Without Access To Users

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Eduard Kuric)
articles.description: In this article, Eduard Kuric discusses mouse interaction data, what kind of magic can be done with it, and some of the hidden pitfalls to watch out for so you get a head start incorporating them in your solutions.
articles.title: How To Harness Mouse Interaction Data For Practical Machine Learning Solutions

articles.author: Quincy Larson

articles.title: How Suz Hinton went from Dev to White Hat Hacker [Podcast #126]

articles.author: Asoluka Tochukwu Austin
articles.description: Prototypal inheritance can feel like a complex concept shrouded in technical jargon. But fear not! This guide will break it down using clear, relatable examples that go beyond the typical textbook explanations.  We'll ditch the confusing terms and focus on real-world scenarios that you can easily understand. By the
articles.title: What is Prototypal Inheritance in JavaScript? Explained with Code Examples

articles.title: Learn the Basics of Go by Building a Full Stack Web App with React and Go

articles.description: Managing state has always been a critical aspect of making web applications with React. The most basic way to do this is prop drilling. In prop drilling, you pass props around from the parent component to other components that need it, no matter how deeply nested they are. The problem
articles.title: React Context API Explained with Examples

articles.author: Zaira Hira
articles.description: Computers perform complex calculations when carrying out their assigned tasks. At the very core, the calculations boil down to operations like comparisons, assignments, and addition. Have you ever wondered how they are performed under the hood and wh...
articles.title: How Do Numerical Conversions Work in Computer Systems? Explained With Examples

articles.author: Anshul Sanghi
articles.description: Iterators and match patterns are two of the most used language features in Rust. If you have written any real world application, big or small, chances are that you've already used these, whether knowingly or unknowingly. In this tutorial, I aim to help you understand how they actually work, the
articles.title: Rust Tutorial – Learn Advanced Iterators & Pattern Matching by Building a JSON Parser

articles.author: Beau Carnes
articles.description: Linear algebra is a useful skill for professionals in data science, machine learning, and AI. We just posted a course on the freeCodeCamp.org YouTube channel that will teach you linear algebra. This crash course spans just over 6 hours and is a great...
articles.title: Linear Algebra Crash Course - Mathematics for Machine Learning and Generative AI

articles.author: Gursimar Singh
articles.description: AWS Local Zones are a new type of infrastructure that enables you to build and run applications closer to end-users, providing low latency and improved performance.  They are designed to provide the same high availability and reliability as an AWS Region, but with the added benefit of low-latency connections
articles.title: How to Build an EKS Cluster Across AWS Local Zones using the AWS CDK

articles.author: Oluwadamisi Samuel Praise
articles.description: Regression models identify trends in a dataset and predict outcomes based on the trends they have analyzed and identified.  Linear and Logistic Regression are two types of regression models that are similar but carry out their functions in distinct ways. They're also two fundamental techniques in machine learning that
articles.title: Linear vs Logistic Regression:  How to Choose the Right Regression Model for Your Data

articles.author: Kunal Nalawade
articles.description: Hi fellow readers! Web Development is a constantly evolving landscape. The whole ecosystem consists of different libraries and technologies. React is one of the most widely used libraries in web development.  There are small releases every now and then. However, this year, the React team has made a significant
articles.title: React 19 – New Hooks Explained with Examples

articles.author: Musab Habeeb
articles.description: Node.js is an open-source JavaScript runtime environment that allows you to run JavaScript outside the browser. Although Node.js is single-threaded, it has an event loop that makes it multi-threaded. The Node.js event loop is a crucial mechanism in Node.js that makes Node.js programs run concurrently and asynchronously. Mastering the Node.js
articles.title: A Guide to the Node.js Event Loop

articles.author: Eric Hu
articles.description: String manipulation is a common task for programmers, whether it is extracting information from the string, converting letter cases, joining strings, or trimming extra white spaces. This tutorial covers various methods and techniques for manipulating strings using JavaScript, offering you a comprehensive guide on how to work with strings in
articles.title: How to Manipulate Strings in JavaScript – With Code Examples

articles.author: Isaiah Cliford  Opoku
articles.description: Welcome to this comprehensive guide on building CRUD operations with .NET Core. We'll use a Todo API as our practical example so you can get hands-on experience as you learn. Throughout this tutorial, you'll learn how to create, read, update, and delete Todo items, and how to leverage Entity Framework
articles.title: How to Build CRUD Operations with .NET Core – A Todo API Handbook

articles.author: Quincy Larson
articles.description: On this week's episode of the podcast, I interview Jerod Santo, host of The Changelog, a podcast about open source software development that has been going strong for 15 years. Jerod is plugged in to the world of Open Source, going to all the big con...
articles.title: Open Source is Changing. The Changelog Host Jerod Santo on How to Keep Up [Podcast #125]

articles.author: Oleg Romanyuk
articles.description: Proof of concept, prototypes, wireframes, mockups… what actually constitutes a Minimum Viable Product (MVP)? Well, it's a product with just enough features to gather comprehensive qualitative feedback. In practice, it's as easy to understand the concept of an MVP as it is to ride a bicycle. Let's do it then.
articles.title: How to Build an MVP for Your Project – and Why You Should Do It

articles.author: Juan Cruz Martinez
articles.description: As a developer, I've seen how choosing the "right" tech stack can be a double-edged sword. I often fell into the trap of chasing shiny new technologies, thinking they were the key to building the next great product. But experience has taught me that prioritizing speed to market trends often
articles.title: How to Choose a Tech Stack for Your SaaS Product – Lessons from a Developer
